reviewText:
Early Access Review

Trading card game" is not an appropriate description for this one - a better name would be "Tactical card game". Decromancer differs from most of the card titles out there in that it's much less random and focuses more on placement.
You don't have a "hand" from which to play cards
date: instead - you have a grid on which to place them.\nAll the cards you have are available from the start of a battle
recommended: but you're limited to only 3 creatures per turn.\nThe resources you have to summon cards do not grow with time (only with your character level)
hoursPlayed: so plan wisely\nCreature cards have attack patterns on the grid
voteText: so their placement matter a LOT..and of course many also have special abilities
helpfulPercent: but that's not so novel.\n\nThe game is a port from mobile devices and so one should be prepared for some characteristic elements that are more suited to mobile
votesHelpful: but the developer is still working on implementing some additions to make use of what PCs have to offer - like hotkeys. There's still traces of microtransactions here and there
votesTotal: but honestly - you never needed to make those in the first place - all the game has to offer is avalable through normal play. Sure it does mean a bit of grinding
votesFunny: but  not an awful lot and the grind itself is not a a boring thing you just keep doing over and over - replaying some known battles actually lets you try out some different tactics and polish up your skills.\n\nThere are of course some bad sides - biggest of all is that the game is mostly singleplayer. The only mp element is a hotseat skirmish. Decromancer doesn't make use of network connections

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game that is ultimately just a port from tablet gaming, it is plagued with bugs that are very likely to simply stop you from progressing any further into the game. Quest items to pick up are particularly guilty of this: some of them will eventually be picked up after one or two crashes, but some never do, and one of them might just make you unable to do anything else than grinding while waiting for a fix.

The main problem with that, is that you will be playing for more than 2 hours before running into a brick wall, at which point Steam will not refund you even though the full game is basically not playable.

A very great game that I had the chance to enjoy through a third party software as its mobile version, but saying that the game is FINISHED is a joke. I don't own a tablet/smartphone and I was very happy to support the developer when it was finally released on PC, but it's been released here 5 months ago and even basic functions aren't working properly (I crashed during the tutorial battle, for example) despite the fact that the devs announced 1 or 2 months to polish it up.

Good game. In theory. It had better be completely bug-free after Early Access if they plan to push the price up once it is done. If it ever gets done.
